choices.text: Hyper acute graft rejection is most commonly seen with renal transplant.
Most common tumour after transplantation is Squamous cell carcinoma of skin.
GVHD is most commonly associated with allogeneic bone marrow transplant.
Hyper acute graft rejection is an example of type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: All of the following are correct about graft rejection, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hyperacute rejection occurs due to preformed antibodies which is TYPE II HSN RX.

questions.text: Match the following IHC markers with their associated malignancy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CD99 or MIC 2 is also POSITIVE in GCT Ovary.

questions.text: What is the type of inheritance seen in the image given below?
A child presented with thymic hypoplasia, decreased immunity and hypocalcemia. He also has tetralogy of fallot. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CATCH 22 features digeorge syndrome which includes thymic hypoplasia, decreased t-cell immunity and hypocalcemia.

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with a condition due to a DNA repair gene defect. He is having mottled hyperpigmentation on the skin and is at high risk of developing skin cancers as per the physician. Which of the following is a likely enzyme defect in the patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Nucleotide excision repair defect causes xeroderma pigmentosa and skin SCC.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man has a health screening examination. He has a routine chest x-ray that shows a 2 cm nodule in the right lower lobe. The nodule has focal calcifications. A wedge resection of the lung with the nodule is performed. On microscopic examination the nodule shows caseous necrosis and calcification. Which of the following processes best explains the appearance of the calcium deposition in his lung nodule?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Caseating necrosis and calcification suggest TB is an example of dystrophic calcification.

questions.text: A 42-year old male experienced dyspnea for past 3 months. A chest CT scan shows a posterior mediastinal mass measuring 5 x 6 cm. Mass is biopsied and on histology there are scattered large multinucleated with prominent nucleoli which are positive for CD 15 and CD 30 CDand lymphocytes and macrophages separated by dense collagenous bands. Which of the following is likely to be seen microscopically in this biopsy specimen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CD15, CD30 positive suggest HL along with dense collagenous band suggest nodular sclerosing variant which shows lacunar cells.

choices.text: Increased Ca++ ions in the cytosol

questions.text: The major mechanism of damage to plasma membrane in ischaemia is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased ca2+ activates phospholipase which damages cell membranes

questions.text: A 28-year old female patient presented with chronic fatigue in December. On examination she was found having mild splenomegaly, peripheral cyanosis over tips of nose and fingers. Peripheral smear was prepared and it was showing the features given below. What would be the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Agglutinated RBC due to cold agglutinin AlHA (Auto-Immune Hemolytic Anaemia)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man has had headaches, dizziness, and fatigue for the past 3 months. His friends have been commenting about his increasingly ruddy complexion. He also has experienced generalised and severe pruritus, particularly when showering. He notes that his stools are dark. On physical Examination, he is afebrile, and his blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg. There is no hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy. A stool sample is positive for occult blood. CBC shows haemoglobin, 22.3 g/d; hematocrit, 67.1%; MCV, 94 m3; platelet count, 453,000/mm3; and WBC count, 7800/mm3. The serum erythropoietin level is very low. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year old boy presents with mass in his abdomen. On imaging the para aortic LN is enlarged and biopsy has revealed the following histopathological image. What is the most likely underlying abnormality in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Translocation involving MYC gene

His chest radiograph shows patchy infiltrates, and a culture of sputum grows Mycobacterium. Which of the following laboratory findings is most characteristic of this disorder?

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct? A. Whole blood and packed red cells are stored at 2-6°C for 42 days. B. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is kept at below-18°C for 10 years. C. Platelets are kept at 20-24°C (room temperature) for 5 days with continuous agitation. D. Cryoprecipitate is kept below-18°C for 10 years.
questions.solution:

A and C are correct

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, muscle weakness, and stroke-like episodes. questions.text: A 45-year old male patient presented to Emergency wing with heartburn and increased salivation. Upper GI Endoscopy was carried out, and biopsy was taken. (See Photograph below). Most likely diagnosis is:

questions.text: A 9-year old child presents with hypoalbuminemia, edema, hyperlipidemia and proteinuria. The edema in the periorbital region initially and eventually spreads to the rest of the body. The patient is given steroid therapy and the disease goes away. What is a key morphological feature of the patient's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The child with proteinuria and steroid responsive suggestive of MINIMAL CHANGE DISEASE which shows fusion of foot process.

questions.text: A 55-year old male presented to OPD with fever, weight loss, fatigue and pallor. CBC shows: Hb-9gm/dl TLC-117000/cmm Platelet count-1,60,000/cmm Myeloid blasts <11% Basophils - 4% Most probable diagnosis:

Correct Answer (A)

Increased tlc count with basophilia and myeloblast less then 20% suggest CML

questions.text: A 55-year old man underwent an operation for lipoma. 11 months after surgery, he felt severe itching and burning on the operated site where a scar is formed which is limited to the wound boundary. What is the nature of this lesion?

Scar limited to boundaries of wound suggest hypertrophic scar.
